on a purl row purl as normal but through 2 stitches at the same time to decrease your stitch count colourwork tips floats lots of us have been taught at some point to always twist the two yarns when changing colour* but in fair isle style knitting this can make the knitting process unnecessarily difficult as well as making your fabric too dense and distorting your stitches when i look at my work from the back i want to be able to clearly see the two colours running in straight lines one above the other if you find that your stitch gauge is too tight in stranded knitting it might be that you aren t keeping your floats loose enough the float is the unused strand of yarn that runs along the back of your work whilst you re knitting in the other colour you can use your fingers to stretch your work out a little along your needles in between each repeat of the pattern catching long floats i ll start by saying that traditional fair isle knitting publications usually discourage catching floats and prefer to carry the unused yarn strands along the back of the fabric in my opinion this only works if you have perfect gauge which takes hours or years of practice as some of you may not be experienced colour work knitters and because i have created my own repeat patterns which have long gaps in between motifs and because your scarf may be worn with coats that have buttons or toggles that can catch long floats i am giving you permission to catch long floats here is how you catch a long float in colourwork knitting this works for all styles of knitting english continental right or left handed 1 bring your float yarn behind your working yarn 2 twist your float yarn around your working yarn this pattern is for personal non-commercial use only the pattern may not be copied resold or redistributed in any way 3 hold your float yarn away from your working yarn as you knit your next stitch the general guide is that it is only necessary on floats longer than 2 5cm so you will probably only need this on days 6 8 10 17 18 & 20 where i have created my own wide spaced repeat motifs * intarsia this technique will be used near either end of a row where the colour work pattern repeat finishes before the i cord edge to avoid holes or gaps in the knitting when changing colours the two different colour yarns are twisted around each other on every row see image right which
